content.title: Temperature & Humidity for Leopard Geckos
content.content: Proper temperature gradients and humidity levels are critical for leopard gecko health. This guide covers target zones, heating equipment, measurement tools, and common issues to ensure your gecko can thermoregulate effectively.
Leopard geckos are ectothermic (cold-blooded) and require a temperature gradient to regulate body temperature behaviorally. They move between zones depending on metabolic needs.

rows: Basking Surface
Surface of basking stone/substrate under heat lamp
Digestion, immune function activation
Warm Hide Interior
Air temp inside warm hide
Secure thermoregulation while hidden
Warm End Ambient
Air temp in warm side of enclosure, 4-6" off substrate
General warm zone activity
Cool End Ambient
Air temp in cool side of enclosure, 4-6" off substrate
Cooling down, resting after basking
Night Temperature
Ambient enclosure temp after lights off
Natural temp drop; 60F minimum acceptable

content.content: Surface Temperature Critical: Basking SURFACE (not air temp) must be 94-97F. Use infrared temp gun to measure surface temps. Stick-on thermometers measure air temp and are INACCURATE for reptile care.

Temperature Gradient Purpose: Gradient allows gecko to choose temperature zone based on needs. After eating, gecko moves to basking spot (94-97F) for digestion. Once warmed, gecko moves to cool zone (70-77F). Inadequate gradient prevents proper thermoregulation.

content.text: Recommended: Overhead Halogen Heat Bulbs

items: Why Halogen: Mimics natural sun, provides deep tissue heating (infrared A), warms both air and surfaces efficiently
Wattage: 75w for 36"x18" enclosure (adjust based on room temp - cooler rooms need 100w)
Fixture: Ceramic socket dome lamp rated for bulb wattage, positioned over warm hide
Bulb Examples: Arcadia Halogen Heat Lamp, Zoo Med Repti Basking Spot (halogen version), Philips EcoVantage Halogen PAR38
Distance: 8-12 inches above basking surface (adjust to achieve 94-97F surface temp)
Dimming Thermostat REQUIRED: Herpstat, VE, Spyder Robotics - prevents overheating and maintains consistent temps

content.text: Alternative: Deep Heat Projectors (DHP)

items: Emit infrared A and B wavelengths (deep tissue heating) without visible light
Excellent for night heating if room temps drop below 60F
Examples: Arcadia Deep Heat Projector, Pangea DHP
Use with dimming thermostat to maintain 70-75F night temps if needed
Higher cost than halogen bulbs ($50-80 vs. $10-15)

content.text: Acceptable Supplement: Ceramic Heat Emitters (CHE)

items: Emit  infrared C (surface heating only, does not penetrate tissue)
No visible light - good for 24hr heat if room temps unstable
Less effective than halogen or DHP but workable
Examples: Fluker's Ceramic Heat Emitter, Zoo Med ReptiCare CHE
Requires pulse-proportional thermostat (NOT on/off thermostat)

content.content: NEVER Use Heat Rocks or Heat Cables: These cause severe thermal burns on gecko belly. Leopard geckos cannot sense heat on their belly and will sit on dangerously hot surfaces. Deaths and severe injuries common. ALWAYS use overhead heating.

content.text: Under-Tank Heaters (UTH) - Use with Caution:

items: Can provide supplemental belly heat if used correctly, but NOT as primary heat source
MUST be regulated with thermostat - unregulated UTH causes burns
Place under only 1/3 of enclosure (warm end) to allow gecko to move away
Max surface temp: 88-90F (measure with temp gun through substrate)
Better option: Use overhead heat and skip UTH entirely

content.content: Minimum Equipment: Infrared temp gun ($15-30) + 2 digital thermometers with probes ($10-15 each) + dimming thermostat ($100-180). Do NOT skimp on temperature equipment - these tools prevent fatal overheating and ensure proper thermoregulation.

content.text: Step 1: Install Heat Source

items: Position dome fixture with 75w halogen bulb over warm hide area (1/3 of enclosure)
Start with bulb 10 inches above substrate/basking surface
Connect heat bulb to dimming thermostat
Place thermostat probe at basking spot surface (touching where gecko will bask)

content.text: Step 2: Calibrate Basking Temp

items: Set thermostat to 95F and allow 30-60 minutes to stabilize
Use infrared temp gun to measure basking surface temperature
Target: 94-97F on surface of basking stone or substrate under heat lamp
Adjust thermostat setting OR bulb height if temp incorrect (increase height = lower temp; decrease height = higher temp)
Recheck after each adjustment and allow 30 min to stabilize

content.text: Step 3: Verify Warm Hide Temp

items: Place digital thermometer probe inside warm hide (center of hide, substrate level)
Target: 90-92F inside hide
If too hot (>92F): Move hide slightly away from heat source or increase bulb height
If too cool (<90F): Move hide closer to heat source or decrease bulb height

content.text: Step 4: Verify Cool End Temp

items: Place digital thermometer probe in cool end (opposite side from heat source, 4-6 inches off substrate)
Target: 70-77F ambient air temp
If too warm (>77F): Room temp too high, increase ventilation or move enclosure to cooler room; OR reduce heat bulb wattage
If too cool (<70F): Acceptable for cooling down; gecko should primarily be in warm zones if cool end below 70F

content.text: Step 5: Monitor for 24-48 Hours

items: Check temps with infrared gun 4-6 times over 24 hours to ensure stability
Measure basking surface, warm hide interior, cool end ambient every 6 hours
Adjust thermostat if temps fluctuate more than 3F
Verify night temps after lights off - should drop naturally to 60-75F (if room temp drops below 60F, add DHP or CHE for night heat)

content.content: Seasonal Adjustments: Room temperature changes with seasons. Summer may require lower wattage bulb or increased ventilation. Winter may need higher wattage or supplemental heat source. Recheck temps monthly and adjust as needed.
Leopard geckos come from arid environments and require LOW ambient humidity with access to a HIGH humidity humid hide for shedding.

rows: Ambient Enclosure
General enclosure air humidity (measured with hygrometer)
Prevents respiratory infections, mimics natural arid habitat
Humid Hide Interior
Inside enclosed humid hide with moist substrate
Facilitates healthy shedding, prevents stuck shed
During Shed
40-50% ambient okay
Ambient can spike slightly during shed (2-3 days)
Temporary increase acceptable, return to 30-40% after shed complete

content.content: High Ambient Humidity Risk: Sustained ambient humidity above 50% increases respiratory infection risk. If room humidity consistently high (tropical climates, humid basements), increase ventilation or use dehumidifier in room.

content.text: Maintaining Humid Hide:

items: Use enclosed hide (single entrance or two entrances) - must be enclosed on top to trap moisture
Fill hide with moist sphagnum moss (squeeze out excess water - should clump but not drip)
Alternative substrates: Paper towels kept damp (change every 2-3 days), coconut fiber (mist lightly)
Position humid hide in middle or slightly toward cool end (NOT under basking light - heat dries it out)
Mist humid hide substrate with spray bottle every 2-3 days to maintain 70-80% humidity inside
Use small digital hygrometer inside hide to verify humidity level (optional but recommended)
Replace sphagnum moss entirely every month (mold prevention)

content.content: Humid Hide is NON-NEGOTIABLE: Even with "perfect" 30-40% ambient humidity, leopard geckos REQUIRE a humid hide for healthy shedding. Geckos without humid hides experience stuck shed (especially toes, tail tip, eyelids) which can lead to tissue death and digit loss.

rows: Enclosure too cold overall
Gecko constantly basking, lethargic, refuses food, slow digestion
Insufficient heat bulb wattage, room too cold, thermostat set too low
Increase bulb wattage (75w  100w), verify basking surface 94-97F, check thermostat setting
Basking spot too hot
Gecko avoids basking area entirely, thermal burns on belly
Thermostat malfunction, bulb too close, no thermostat used
Install or replace thermostat, increase bulb distance, verify surface temp with temp gun
No temperature gradient
Gecko cannot thermoregulate, stays in one location constantly
Enclosure too small (<36"x18"), heat source too powerful, poor ventilation
Upgrade to 36"x18" minimum, reduce bulb wattage, ensure screen lid for ventilation
Cool end too warm
Gecko overheats, no cool refuge, panting (open-mouth breathing)
Room temp too high, enclosure in direct sunlight, inadequate ventilation
Move enclosure away from windows, increase ventilation, reduce heat bulb wattage, use fan in room
Night temps drop below 60F
Gecko very inactive at night, cool to touch in morning
Room temp drops significantly overnight (common in winter)
Add Deep Heat Projector or CHE for night heat (70-75F), use thermostat to regulate night temps
Ambient humidity too high (>50%)
Respiratory issues (wheezing, mucus bubbles), lethargy
Room naturally humid, insufficient ventilation, over-misting
Increase ventilation, use dehumidifier in room, reduce misting frequency, ensure screen lid (not glass)
Stuck shed on toes/tail/eyes
Retained skin after shedding, constricted digits, cloudy eyes
Humid hide not provided OR humid hide too dry (<70%)
Provide enclosed humid hide with damp sphagnum moss, mist hide every 2-3 days, verify 70-80% inside hide
Humid hide dries out quickly
Moss dries within 24 hours of misting
Hide placed under basking light, hide not fully enclosed, low-humidity room
Move hide away from heat source, use fully enclosed hide, mist more frequently (daily vs. every 3 days)

content.text: Daily Tasks:

items: Visually check digital thermometer readings (warm and cool zones)
Ensure heat lamp is functioning (look for visible light if halogen)
Check gecko behavior - basking briefly then moving to cool end = correct temps; constant basking = too cold; hiding all day = may be too hot
Glance at hygrometer - ambient should stay 30-40%

content.text: Every 2-3 Days:

items: Mist humid hide substrate with spray bottle (3-5 sprays) - sphagnum moss should feel damp to touch
Use infrared temp gun to spot-check basking surface temp (should still be 94-97F)

content.text: Weekly Tasks:

items: Measure temps at all locations with infrared gun: basking surface, warm hide interior, cool end ambient
Record temps in log (notebook or phone app) to track any drift over time
Check humid hide for mold - if mold present, replace sphagnum moss immediately

content.text: Monthly Tasks:

items: Replace humid hide sphagnum moss entirely (mold prevention even if not visible)
Test thermostat function: unplug thermostat briefly, verify bulb runs full power, replug and verify thermostat regulates temp again
Inspect heat bulb for damage or blackening - replace if degraded
Clean thermometer/hygrometer probes with damp cloth (dust buildup affects accuracy)

content.text: Every 6-12 Months:

items: Replace heat bulb even if still functioning (output degrades over time, especially halogen)
Calibrate or replace infrared temp gun if readings seem inconsistent (test against known temp like boiling water 212F)
Deep clean enclosure and all equipment during full substrate change

content.content: Temperature Logs Prevent Issues: Recording temps weekly helps identify gradual drift (e.g., basking temp slowly dropping from 95F to 88F over 2 months). Catching drift early prevents health issues and identifies equipment failures before they become critical.
Leopard gecko behavior reveals whether temperature gradient is correct:

rows: Basking for 30-60 min after lights on or after eating, then moves to cool zone
Normal thermoregulation - temps are correct
None - this is ideal behavior
Constantly on basking spot, rarely leaves warm end
Enclosure too cold overall, gecko trying to reach adequate body temp
Check basking surface with temp gun - increase to 94-97F; verify warm hide 90-92F
Avoids warm end entirely, stays in cool hide all day
Warm end too hot, gecko overheating, or gecko ill
Check basking temp - reduce if >97F; verify cool end <77F; monitor for illness signs
Glass surfing (pacing at front glass)
Room temp too high, enclosure overheating, stress, or hunger
Check all temps with temp gun; reduce heat if needed; verify cool zone exists; check feeding schedule
Digging in substrate constantly
Trying to escape heat (too hot), natural burrowing behavior, or gravid female
Check temps first; if temps correct, provide deeper substrate (3-4 inches) for burrowing enrichment
Lethargic, eyes closed during active hours (dusk)
Temperatures too cold (slows metabolism), or illness
Verify basking 94-97F, warm hide 90-92F; if temps correct, vet check recommended
